they're great and they patch a whole bunch of holes in the web platform that we don't have anymore so be it's Felts
or reacts or what have you they all add a module system and they all add a
component system and then they compile that away to generate HTML and we realized that the browser has these
things the browser didn't used to have a module system famously for a really long time but we we now have pretty
ubiquitous es modules and the browser has a component system called Web
components which it does has a story maybe a surprise to some like it's
there it's been there a long time but it seems like people are just realizing it's in there well and you know it went
through some classic software iteration it took a while for it to kind of come up to speed and it's got limitations but
it's good you know these things are built in now and you can extend HTML natively you can create your own
elements you can open up Dev tools you can see those elements inspect them change them and this is pretty nice uh
compared to the div soup that we get from transpilers that generate code you you get more of an even match between
what you write and what you run which makes debugging better but even better still you're not sending a bunch of code
to userland to do stuff the browser can already do so you get better performance as a result and one of the big holes
with web components is that they're they're very client side JavaScript Centric you implement a class by
extending HTML element and then you register that uh with the custom elements Define call which runs client
side so this happens after client side JavaScript kicks in and we wanted to do
a lot of stuff before client side JavaScript kicks in if you take like a normal web page page just like any given
web page most of the elements on that page are inert they they don't have
event listeners they're just sitting there yeah they're just hanging out you know drawing boxes or whatever and
that's great but it's funny because our whole programming model is Downstream thinking about JavaScript or HTML
elements as something JavaScript created manages and maintains and and that's kind of inefficient so server rendering
is becoming popular again which is great because uh that performs better and it's
it's also closer to how how the ultimate page works you know you just get a bunch of a nerd HTML and then you can kind of
save your client side JavaScript for the stuff that client side JavaScript can only do so enhance is a way to server
render web components and we're unique in this way there's there's other projects that are sort of attempting to
do this through build steps and stuff um but they're not quite there yet and we took approach that was a little bit
different than other projects like lit whereas lit like wants to think about the whole world is like JavaScript
executes and some events fire and then I insert some HTML inside of myself and
we're inverting that and saying Define templates using JavaScript using just plain JavaScript and then we'll render
those templates and expand all the elements for you uh with State on the server side and if you want on the
client you can then also run JavaScript but for the vast majority the elements
that you're producing for a web page you won't need to do that so the classic kind of example I like to give is your
header and your footer of your website those probably don't need JavaScript but they definitely need to render and
they're going to have a whole bunch of elements like links and stuff sure and you want to pump those out into the page
as quick as possible so people can have a good user experience at the end of the day they can navigate around if
JavaScript fails you still get some UI and um yeah if you want at that moment
you know you can run client side JavaScript and do whatever you want inside of that so so that's what enhance does at a high level it's server side
rendering a web components and that's been fun and we like that and uh one of our devs came
across a blog post from Shopify where they were working with a thing called wasm time and quickjs and they had
created a way to compile quickjs into wum with the JavaScript module and then
be able to execute that in any wasm compatible runtime so most of the time when we
think about wasm or wasm however you like sure which it is but yeah I'm
Canadian so I sometimes say JavaScript so maybe I should say w I would appreciate you to say JavaScript every
time JavaScript I like unlearned that going to conferences because people just
look at me and be like ja who is this guy um usually when we think of was we think let's take some native code and
run that in the browser which is a cool use case and brought a whole bunch of stuff to the browser this technique that
the Shopify guys figured out lets us take JavaScript browser stuff and run that in different backend run times and
so one of our devs was like wow I wonder if I could run the enhanced SSR module
in wasum and if we could could we then server render JavaScript components from
different backend runtimes like Java or PHP or Ruby python rust whatever and um
it worked which we were all kind of surprised yeah it seems like I wouldn't
say a hack but it seems kind of roundabout or something it feels hacky yeah know it does cuz we're we're
bringing a whole JavaScript runtime to the party and and like there's a whole bunch of immediate things you think like
one if you're bringing a whole JavaScript runtime into wasm that's got to be big right like that's got to be fast or slow slow big and it's it's not
it's fast it's tiny yeah it's pretty quick you you end up with like a 3 megabyte payload but on the service side
that's not as big of a deal right and um this opens up a whole bunch of really cool use cases so in the past we've kind
of maintained a good clean separation between our front ends and back ends but that does create its own problems with
those separations of concern so if I build my whole front end and react that's great but now if I want to server
render anything I have to run node exactly or you know or a bun or something like that and a lot of shops
don't do that like there's tons of shops out there that are running Java python or whatever so they end up with spinners
they end up with a fully client rendered app skeleton screens and poor user experience as a result and that's a
bummer so this technique would allow them to do a design system build a bunch
of components and still be able to server render them in any backend runtime that they want which is pretty
exciting I agree with you 100% which is why I was immediately excited about this
and I immediately reached out and I was like this seems like this could be I I don't want to overuse the term
gamechanging and of course it does feel like a hack but the possibilities it opens up are really big for a lot of
shops and so I want to get the word out about it because it seems like it could be a really good thing for a lot of people well and I don't think it has to
be just us so there's a lot of zero some thinking these days in open source but you know now now the road is paved so
there's nothing saying someone can't take this technique and use this uh for other types of renderers so like maybe
you want to use handlebars on the client's server and get that in both places or maybe you want to try and get
react working I don't think it will work very well from a performance perspective but it's worth a shot and um yeah
there's the kind of big example for me uh has been Design Systems so this is a
a pretty big Trend these days it kind of comes out of big Coe so if you've ever worked at a big company you you quickly
learn that big companies don't grow kind of organically they grow through acquisition and what ends up happening
is you get a big company that's actually 10 or 11 companies in a trench coat and
each one of those Acquisitions has a different stack every oh for sure yeah and so so Design Systems came around
we're like what we'll do is we will have a cohesive UI for our entire portfolio
of products and we basically be reimplementing that in each one of these stacks and so if you've got a you know
your blogs in WordPress you're going to be implementing the look and feel inside a PHP but if you know the main app is
running in Java spring you're going to be jumping into a thing called time leaf and if parts of the app are written in
node you're going to be jumping over to node so this would let you have a design
system with a single set of definitions and you would lose that kind of uncanny valley of having to reimplement
everything in every every different back end which is which is pretty cool yeah for me it also opens up the possibility
of just globally sharing of components right like across every stack it's like well here's a web component that this
person wrote It's really high quality it does all the things it has all the accessibility built in like everything's
been thought through and now if you can basically run wasam on your back end
which is most languages at this point then you can server side render that sucker and just integrate it into your
application no matter what you're doing or where you are and I think that's pretty cool I think it opens up a lot
